questions.question: You arrive in Utopia, a seemingly perfect society. You are greeted by its people, and everything appears idyllic. Days pass, and you begin to settle into your new life. As you become more integrated into the system, the voice of your past haunts you: 'You allowed humanity to fall from paradise. Is this not the second chance you sought? A perfect society of perfect humans' Yet doubts grow. What will you do?

choices.text: You appreciate the society and wish to stay

questions.question: Staying in Utopia is much easier than getting out. Easily, you survive. You move day in, day out through your duties. But, living there is much harder.
You decide to leave, but Utopia doesnâ€™t make it easy. What's your plan?

choices.text: Lie low, gathering time to plan your escape.

questions.question: The very first person you talk to report you. Unfortunate, but now, you are on Utopia's watchlist and are never ever leaving.
Rushing out to the countryside, you are quickly captured by Utopian officials and put to death for trying to escape.

You lie low. You integrate. You slowly become used to your new life and find comfort in your routine. What is a couple weeks or monthes? You have friends here now and a purpose in society. Do you still plan your escape?

choices.text: Yes. I still want to get out.

questions.question: You resolute yourself to your goal. Trying to do this the offical way, you walk out, seeking to ask Utopian officals to travel and use that as a means of escape. However, when walking, you see a penny face up. That's good luck. Do you pick it up?
Immediately, the Utopian government that sees all grabs you. Your own penny! You clearly haven't given up ownership. You have been on thin ice, but now, for a lucky penny, you are put to death.

Without picking up the penny, you reach Utopian officer, who you resolutely ask to be allowed to travel. He looks at you careful. Prepared to answer many questions about why you wanted to travel, with who, and to where, you were not prepared to be asked about a secret on of your only friends in Utopia made to you. Why is the officer interested in such a harmless secret? Should you share it or respect your friendship?

The officer, unimpressed with you, sniffles before saying that such attachment to people is individualistic for there is no reason to hold such unhealthy attachment. Therefore, your request has been denied and so will all future ones. Enjoy life in Utopia.

You pass and are allowed to travel, letting you escape. But at what price? You reflect on the penny and the secret. Such small, silly details could've cost you your life. But, why couldn't you keep them? You notice how, when trying to fit in the perfect society, you become less human. You carry the weight of a missing penny and lost secret for the rest of your life- or at least, what you hope is a life.
